elements.content: Semiconductive metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted extraordinary research interest in recent years; however, electronic applications based on these emerging materials are still in their infancy. Herein, we show that a lanthanide-based semiconductive MOF (SCU-12) can effectively convert X-ray photons to electrical current signals under continuous hard X-ray radiation. The semiconductive MOF-based polycrystalline detection device presents a promising X-ray sensitivity with the value of 23.8 μC Gyair –1 cm–2 under 80 kVp X-ray exposure, competitive with the commercially available amorphous selenium (α-Se) detector. The lowest detectable X-ray dose rate is 0.705 μGy s–1, representing the record value among all X-ray detectors fabricated by polycrystalline materials. This work discloses the first demonstration of hard radiation detection by semiconductive MOFs, providing a horizon that can guide the synthesis of a new generation of radiation detection materials by taking the advantages of structural designability and property tunability in the MOF system.

elements.content: Detection of X-ray photons is critical in multipurpose fields including medical diagnostics and therapeutics, homeland security, astrophysics, and scientific facilities. Compared with scintillator-based indirect detection materials, semiconductors can directly convert X-ray photons to charge carriers, with the merits of improved energy and spatial resolution, as well as more portable packaging. Over the past decades, versatile semiconductors were prolifically developed for detecting X-ray photons. These materials include amorphous Se, crystalline Ge/Si, crystalline PbI2, TlBr, Cd­(Zn)Te (CZT), and halides-based ternary compounds. Although many of these materials have been commercialized, they face severe bottlenecks in practical applications. For example, the utilization of Si and Se is limited within a narrow spectrum range with energy below 40 keV due to poor X-ray absorptivity and low detection efficiency in the high energy regime. The band gap of Ge is only 0.7 eV, leading to high leakage current, and therefore it has to be utilized strictly below the cryogenic temperature. In addition, feasible crystal growth and processing are the critical requirements to produce chemically stable and cost-effective materials. An efficient radiation detection material is recognized with traits of high Zeff, large signal-to-noise ratio and low leakage current, as well as large charge carrier mobility and lifetime product (μτ).

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) assembled by metal nodes/clusters and organic linkers are an emerging class of materials with high crystallinity, inherent porosity, designable architecture, and tunable functionalities, which provides a diverse platform for developing functional materials for many different applications. However, their applications toward radiation detection is quite scarce. Recently, only three cases of “scintillating MOFs” exhibit the radiation induced luminescence. To the best of our knowledge, direct radiation detection materials have never been reported for MOFs, which may partially due to the lagging development of the semiconductive MOFs. The recent research frontier of semiconductive MOFs focuses on achieving high electrical conductivity toward applications in the chemiresistive sensor, field-effect transistors, and supercapacitors. However, detection of hard radiation is impractical using these reported semiconductive MOFs, primarily owing to the poor X-ray absorptivity of light elements for constructing the MOFs and low signal-noise ratio from high leakage current.

elements.content: Herein, we report the first investigation on the detection of X-ray photons by a terbium-based semiconductive MOF, [(CH3)2NH2]­Tb2L3(DMF)2(H2O)2(HCOO) (SCU-12, L = C6Cl2O4 2–). Semiquinoid ligand was selected as the conducting medium given its accessible redox-active property (). As shown in a, comparison results on the attenuation efficiency of representative detection materials Si, SCU-12, and isotypical compounds by altering Tb3+ with lighter elements of Al3+ and In3+ confirm our hypothesis. Higher attenuation efficiency of heavy elements provides a design criterion for radiation detection MOFs. Another comparison on the calculated mass attenuation coefficients between SCU-12 and state of art detection materials are shown in .

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that SCU-12 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c (). The anionic framework of SCU-12 is a relatively dense three-dimensional structure with the charge-balancing [(CH3)2NH2]+ in the pore along the b axis (b). This dense structure endows SCU-12 with excellent stability in water solutions with pH ranging from 1 to 12 (). Tb3+ ions adopt the nine-coordinate capped square antiprismatic geometry, whose oxo-donors are provided by three bidentate ligands, one formate, one coordinated water molecule, and one DMF molecule (). Each semiquinoid ligand chelates and bridges two adjacent Tb3+ ions. Infrared spectrum displays the characteristic carbonyl stretching modes (), confirming the dianionic ligands in SCU-12. The C–O distances for semiquinoid ligands are in the range of 1.244(9)-1.283(9) Å, supporting the valence assignment of ligands. A pronounced absorption peak from 480 to 660 nm in UV–vis absorption spectrum () demonstrates that the band structure of SCU-12 is predominated by the ligand, and the calculated energy gap is 1.84 eV. The multiple spectroscopic features of SCU-12 indicate an almost negligible orbital overlap between Tb3+ and semiquinoid ligands, and the electrons are mainly delocalized within the ligands. This is critical for the control of leakage current, an extremely important parameter for hard radiation detection applications.

elements.content: To investigate the optoelectronic properties of SCU-12, we fabricated a planar MOF-based radiation detector. As shown in c, the SCU-12 wafer with symmetric structure Au/SCU-12/Au was further embedded in a cathode irradiation configuration (c, inset), propitious for minimizing the circuit noise in detecting X-ray photons. The scanning electron microscope images show the morphology, compactness, and crystalline boundaries of the pelleted SCU-12 ( d). The thickness of the detector is about 0.6–0.8 mm, enough to deposit incident X-ray photons. We initially measured the leakage current of the detector under dark conditions. a shows the I–V characteristics of the SCU-12-based detector, showing a linear I–V relationship in the voltage range from −10 to +10 V with the leakage current on the level of 10–12–10–9 A. In addition, this detector can work in the voltage range from −100 to +100 V (), suggesting a high field stability. The resistivity derived from the I–V curve is 1.6 × 1011 Ω·cm, comparable with the commercial radiation detectors such as CZT and TlBr (). This high resistivity is obtained from the bulk sample of SCU-12 without a delicate control of crystal growth and chemical composition. Upon X-ray irradiation, the photocurrent dramatically increases, indicating the charge carriers are effectively generated. The X-ray irradiation on materials often leads to the degradation of the detection performance. We therefore monitored the operational stability of SCU-12 under continuous X-ray irradiation with the accumulated dosage up to 36 Gy. As shown in b, only 1.5% reduction of photocurrent was observed, demonstrating an excellent radiation resistance of detector under working conditions. In addition, SCU-12 maintains the structural integrity after 60 kGy 60Co gamma ray irradiation (). This likely originates from the large conjugated fragment in the structure of SCU-12 that can substantially stabilize the radiation induced radical-based intermediates, highlighting a notable advantage of MOFs in hard radiation detection.

elements.content: The X-ray detection performance was evaluated by investigating the detection sensitivity and the detection limit of dose rate, quantitative figures of merit for radiation detectors. The SCU-12-based detector was exposed under a medical radiation device with a tungsten anode X-ray source. The tube voltage was fixed at 80 kVp and tube current can be controlled from 1 μA to 0.6 mA, corresponding to the calibrated dose rate in the range of 0.705–423 μGy s–1 (). c shows the time-dependent photocurrent of the detector under the different bias voltage at 423 μGy s–1 X-ray irradiation. Promisingly, as a result of high resistivity under dark condition, the on/off ratio reaches 35 under 1 V bias voltage, suggesting the detector is highly sensitive to the X-ray photons. The X-ray detection sensitivity (S) of the SCU-12-based detector is defined as the normalizing photocurrent by the dose rate and the effective area, and was calculated to be 23.8 μC Gyair –1 cm–2 under 30 V bias voltage (d and ), on the same board with the commercial α-Se detector. The leakage current is actually one of the most important factors determining the detection limit. As shown in e, a detectable signal can be still observed even at the extremely low dose rate of 0.705 μGy s–1 (SNR > 3). This value is significantly improved compared with the recently reported polycrystalline MAPbI3-based detectors (), initially indicating high charge-carrier mobility and low charge trapping concentration of MOF-based materials (thorough and direct comparisons under identical testing conditions using the actual samples of reported materials and the corresponding discussion can be found in ). We also investigated the X-ray response of raw ligand for comparison. As shown in , the X-ray-generated-photocurrent is observed demonstrating the conductivity of ligand; however, the photocurrent is unstable due to the weak absorbility of X-ray. In contrast, the SNR value of SCU-12 reaches up to 12.69 under 1 μA (bias = 1 V), highlighting that the detection capacity originates from the integration of ligands and metal centers. Importantly, with the further optimization of the detector composition and single crystal growth, there remains significant amount of room for improving the detection performance in the MOF system ().

elements.content: To understand the charge transport properties of SCU-12, the charge carrier mobility and lifetime product (μτ) was measured by the X-ray generated photoconductivity method. The μτ is recognized as an evaluation of average diffusion length of charge carrier per unit electric field before annihilation, reflecting the charge collection efficiency (CCE) for X-ray detection materials. As shown in f, the charge collection efficiency gradually increases with the elevation of the applied bias. The μτ was extracted from the photocurrent curve by fitting the single charge carrier approximation Hecht equation to be 1.3 × 10–4 cm2·V–1, Q = Q 0 μ τ V L 2 [ 1 − exp ( L 2 μ τ V ) ] where CCE = Q/Q 0, Q is collected charge, Q 0 is saturated collected charge, V is applied bias, and L is sample thickness. Note the well recognized radiation detection materials including traditional semiconductors, ternary compounds, and organic–inorganic hybrid perovskite are in the range from 10–3 to 10–6 cm2·V–1 (i.e., commercial CZT > 3 × 10–3 cm2·V–1, CsPbBr3 1.34 × 10–3 cm2·V–1, Hg3Te2I2 3.3 × 10–6 cm2·V–1 ).

elements.content: In addition, charge carrier mobility (μ) is another important parameter for evaluating the detector performance. We used time-of-flight (TOF) technique (irradiated by 241Am@5.48 MeV α particles) to probe the carrier mobility (μ) of SCU-12. The carrier drift time was acquired by analyzing the pulse height rise time distribution (10–90% amplitude rise time τ10–90% was selected). a shows the representative voltage pulses induced by α particles at 50–250 V for the SCU-12-based detector. The corresponding 10–90% rise time distributions are in the range of 1–4 μs. The representative histogram of rise time distribution for the detector under 250 V is shown in b for the electron transport. The estimated electron mobility is (3 ± 0.29) cm2·V–1·s–1 (c and ; detailed discussion can be found in , section 15 in the ), which endows SCU-12-based detector with a decent X-ray detection performance. In comparison, among other amorphous and polycrystalline systems, the reported sintered MAPbI3 detectors are in the range of 0.53–19 cm2·V–1·s–1 for holes and in the range of 0.50–6 cm2·V–1·s–1 for electrons, respectively.

elements.content: The foregoing results present the first demonstration of direct detection of hard radiation by a MOF material, and the corresponding detector is featured with a low detection limit of dose rate, a considerable X-ray sensitivity competitive with commercially available amorphous Se detector, and an excellent radiation stability under working conditions. It should be noted that although these working parameters, along with several other key physical property parameters including the charge carrier mobility and the charge carrier mobility and lifetime product, are initially measured to be very promising, they were in fact significantly underestimated because the grain boundary resistance predominates the properties of the polycrystalline detector. Given the intrinsic advantages of MOFs including designable architectures and chemical compositions in addition to the single crystal growth technique, more versatile candidates with much improved capabilities in this system are visible in the near future.
